Rationale
The change to the assessment will bring the module in line with the School of Life Sciences assessment guidelines and will remove the assessment workload.
The minimum student number was changed to enable the module to take place with smaller classes. The MBiolSci programme was added to address an omission.
The learning outcomes have been reworded and the 5th learning outcome (Demonstrate knowledge and critical understanding of the principles of ecology, and how this knowledge has been applied to solve problems.) was removed because it is rather vague, and because problem solving is addressed in the Skills. The skills have been updated to better reflect student activities.
The changes have been discussed with the programme team and will be communicated to the students.

Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
Numeracy

How this is developed:
Directed and self-reading

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
Problem solving skills

How this is developed:

Skill/Other Attribute 3:
Numeracy (application of) manipulation of numbers, general mathematical awareness and its application in practical contexts (e.g. measuring, weighing, estimating and applying formulae)

How this is developed:
Educational Aims
Introduce students to the concepts and principles underlying the dynamic interactions between species within communities and populations; Describe examples taken from across the globe that illustrate the importance of population ecology, pressures on fish stocks, and use of natural predators for biological control processes Describe how mutualistic interactions benefit communities, such as coral reefs and leguminous plants; Explore how knowledge and understanding of species- and community- interactions can help to develop plans for ecological restoration; Develop students’ ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding to solve problems in zoology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to introduce students to the concepts and principles underlying the dynamic interactions within populations and between species within communities. It will draw upon examples taken from across the globe: pressures on fish stocks; use of natural predators for biological control processes; how mutualistic interactions benefit communities, such as coral reefs and leguminous plants. It will also explore how knowledge and understanding of these species and community interactions can help plan for ecological mitigation and restoration. The lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources. Students will begiven guided reading, and regular formative assessment exercises will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module. The module will be assessed by coursework.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Population regulation
• Crashes in fish stocks and the sustainability of harvests
• Density dependence and intraspecific competition
• Models of competition – the logistic curve

Topic 2: Interspecific competition
• Conservation and the invasion of exotics
• Interspecific competition and the Competitive Exclusion Principle
• The Lotka-Volterra model of competition

Topic 3: Predation
• Biological control and the harnessing of predators
• Pattern and process in predator-prey dynamics
• Lotka-Volterra and other models of predator-prey interactions

Topic 4: Mutualisms
• Corals, roots, legumes: the dominance of mutualists in the Earth’s ecosystems
• Trophic mutualisms
• Farmer-protector mutualisms

Topic 5: Ecological succession
• Human despoliation of the landscape and land reclamation
• Large scale ecological succession: primary and secondary
• Disturbance and patch dynamics

Topic 6: Spatial dynamics
• Conservation and the need for sufficient and sufficiently-connected habitat
• Metapopulation dynamics
• Island biogeography

Topic 7: Food webs
• Conservation and the law of unexpected consequences
• Trophic cascades and other indirect interactions
• Top-down and bottom-up control of communities

Topic 8: Community complexity and stability
• Conservation and the fragility of ecosystems
• Complexity and the stability of community structure
• Complexity and the stability of community function
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc). These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – Asynchronous Lectures. Description: Attendance Recorded: No. Notes: This refers to timetabled asynchronous sessions

Teaching Method 2 – Synchronous Lecture sessions. Description: Attendance Recorded: Yes. Notes: This refers to timetabled synchronous sessions

Teaching Method 3 – Synchronous computer practicals. Online. Description: Attendance Recorded: Yes. Notes: This refers to timetabled computer practicals. 2 computer practicals (1h each) + 4 problem-solving sessions associated with these activities (1 h each)

Teaching Method 4 – Self-led (asynchronous) data collection. Description: Attendance Recorded: No. Notes: This refers to 2 timetabled sessions of data collection at home (2h each).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students handle, analyse and report real-world data, in an ecological setting.

Assessment 1 (40%) will be coursework involving an extended piece of writing based around analysis of data collected by the students

Assessment 2 (60%) will be data analysis and essay

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​Analyze the demographic forces acting on populations of single and multiple interacting species, and their consequences;
 LO2 Explain the development of community patterns in time (succession) and in space;​
 LO3 Explain the relationships between structure and function operating at the level of the ecological community;
 LO4 Interpret biological patterns in terms of their dynamics and underlying processes.​

The change to the assessment will bring the module in line with the School of Life Sciences assessment guidelines and will remove the assessment workload.
The minimum student number was changed to enable the module to take place with smaller classes. The MBiolSci programme was added to address an omission.
The learning outcomes have been reworded and the 5th learning outcome (Demonstrate knowledge and critical understanding of the principles of ecology, and how this knowledge has been applied to solve problems.) was removed because it is rather vague, and because problem solving is addressed in the Skills. The skills have been updated to better reflect student activities.
The changes have been discussed with the programme team and will be communicated to the students.

LIFE214
Notes
This module is due to commence in January 2019

Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
Numeracy

How this is developed:
Directed and self-reading

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
Problem solving skills

How this is developed:

Skill/Other Attribute 3:
Numeracy (application of) manipulation of numbers, general mathematical awareness and its application in practical contexts (e.g. measuring, weighing, estimating and applying formulae)

How this is developed:
Educational Aims
Introduce students to the concepts and principles underlying the dynamic interactions between species within communities and populations; Describe examples taken from across the globe that illustrate the importance of population ecology, pressures on fish stocks, and use of natural predators for biological control processes Describe how mutualistic interactions benefit communities, such as coral reefs and leguminous plants; Explore how knowledge and understanding of species- and community- interactions can help to develop plans for ecological restoration; Develop students’ ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding to solve problems in zoology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to introduce students to the concepts and principles underlying the dynamic interactions within populations and between species within communities. It will draw upon examples taken from across the globe: pressures on fish stocks; use of natural predators for biological control processes; how mutualistic interactions benefit communities, such as coral reefs and leguminous plants. It will also explore how knowledge and understanding of these species and community interactions can help plan for ecological mitigation and restoration. The lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources. Students will begiven guided reading, and regular formative assessment exercises will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module. The module will be assessed by coursework.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Population regulation
• Crashes in fish stocks and the sustainability of harvests
• Density dependence and intraspecific competition
• Models of competition – the logistic curve

Topic 2: Interspecific competition
• Conservation and the invasion of exotics
• Interspecific competition and the Competitive Exclusion Principle
• The Lotka-Volterra model of competition

Topic 3: Predation
• Biological control and the harnessing of predators
• Pattern and process in predator-prey dynamics
• Lotka-Volterra and other models of predator-prey interactions

Topic 4: Mutualisms
• Corals, roots, legumes: the dominance of mutualists in the Earth’s ecosystems
• Trophic mutualisms
• Farmer-protector mutualisms

Topic 5: Ecological succession
• Human despoliation of the landscape and land reclamation
• Large scale ecological succession: primary and secondary
• Disturbance and patch dynamics

Topic 6: Spatial dynamics
• Conservation and the need for sufficient and sufficiently-connected habitat
• Metapopulation dynamics
• Island biogeography

Topic 7: Food webs
• Conservation and the law of unexpected consequences
• Trophic cascades and other indirect interactions
• Top-down and bottom-up control of communities

Topic 8: Community complexity and stability
• Conservation and the fragility of ecosystems
• Complexity and the stability of community structure
• Complexity and the stability of community function
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc). These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – Asynchronous Lectures. Description: Attendance Recorded: No. Notes: This refers to timetabled asynchronous sessions

Teaching Method 2 – Synchronous Lecture sessions. Description: Attendance Recorded: Yes. Notes: This refers to timetabled synchronous sessions

Teaching Method 3 – Synchronous computer practicals. Online. Description: Attendance Recorded: Yes. Notes: This refers to timetabled computer practicals. 2 computer practicals (1h each) + 4 problem-solving sessions associated with these activities (1 h each)

Teaching Method 4 – Self-led (asynchronous) data collection. Description: Attendance Recorded: No. Notes: This refers to 2 timetabled sessions of data collection at home (2h each).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students handle, analyse and report real-world data, in an ecological setting.

Assessment 1 (40%) will be coursework involving an extended piece of writing based around analysis of data collected by the students

Assessment 2 (60%) will be data analysis and essay

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

This module aims to introduce students to the concepts and principles underlying the dynamic interactions within populations and between species within communities. It will draw upon examples taken from across the globe: pressures on fish stocks; use of natural predators for biological control processes; how mutualistic interactions benefit communities, such as coral reefs and leguminous plants. It will also explore how knowledge and understanding of these species and community interactions can help plan for ecological mitigation and restoration. The lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources. Students will begiven guided reading, and regular formative assessment exercises will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module. The module will be assessed by coursework.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Population regulation
• Crashes in fish stocks and the sustainability of harvests
• Density dependence and intraspecific competition
• Models of competition – the logistic curve

Topic 2: Interspecific competition
• Conservation and the invasion of exotics
• Interspecific competition and the Competitive Exclusion Principle
• The Lotka-Volterra model of competition

Topic 3: Predation
• Biological control and the harnessing of predators
• Pattern and process in predator-prey dynamics
• Lotka-Volterra and other models of predator-prey interactions

Topic 4: Mutualisms
• Corals, roots, legumes: the dominance of mutualists in the Earth’s ecosystems
• Trophic mutualisms
• Farmer-protector mutualisms

Topic 5: Ecological succession
• Human despoliation of the landscape and land reclamation
• Large scale ecological succession: primary and secondary
• Disturbance and patch dynamics

Topic 6: Spatial dynamics
• Conservation and the need for sufficient and sufficiently-connected habitat
• Metapopulation dynamics
• Island biogeography

Topic 7: Food webs
• Conservation and the law of unexpected consequences
• Trophic cascades and other indirect interactions
• Top-down and bottom-up control of communities

Topic 8: Community complexity and stability
• Conservation and the fragility of ecosystems
• Complexity and the stability of community structure
• Complexity and the stability of community function
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc). These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – Asynchronous Lectures. Description: Attendance Recorded: No. Notes: This refers to timetabled asynchronous sessions

Teaching Method 2 – Synchronous Lecture sessions. Description: Attendance Recorded: Yes. Notes: This refers to timetabled synchronous sessions

Teaching Method 3 – Synchronous computer practicals. Online. Description: Attendance Recorded: Yes. Notes: This refers to timetabled computer practicals. 2 computer practicals (1h each) + 4 problem-solving sessions associated with these activities (1 h each)

Teaching Method 4 – Self-led (asynchronous) data collection. Description: Attendance Recorded: No. Notes: This refers to 2 timetabled sessions of data collection at home (2h each).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students handle, analyse and report real-world data, in an ecological setting.

Assessment 1 (40%) will be coursework involving an extended piece of writing based around analysis of data collected by the students

Assessment 2 (60%) will be data analysis and essay

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes

Rationale
The change to the assessment will bring the module in line with the School of Life Sciences assessment guidelines and will remove the assessment workload.
The minimum student number was changed to enable the module to take place with smaller classes. The MBiolSci programme was added to address an omission.
The learning outcomes have been reworded and the 5th learning outcome (Demonstrate knowledge and critical understanding of the principles of ecology, and how this knowledge has been applied to solve problems.) was removed because it is rather vague, and because problem solving is addressed in the Skills. The skills have been updated to better reflect student activities.
The changes have been discussed with the programme team and will be communicated to the students.

Educational Aims
Introduce students to the concepts and principles underlying the dynamic interactions between species within communities and populations; Describe examples taken from across the globe that illustrate the importance of population ecology, pressures on fish stocks, and use of natural predators for biological control processes Describe how mutualistic interactions benefit communities, such as coral reefs and leguminous plants; Explore how knowledge and understanding of species- and community- interactions can help to develop plans for ecological restoration; Develop students’ ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding to solve problems in zoology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to introduce students to the concepts and principles underlying the dynamic interactions within populations and between species within communities. It will draw upon examples taken from across the globe: pressures on fish stocks; use of natural predators for biological control processes; how mutualistic interactions benefit communities, such as coral reefs and leguminous plants. It will also explore how knowledge and understanding of these species and community interactions can help plan for ecological mitigation and restoration. The lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources. Students will begiven guided reading, and regular formative assessment exercises will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module. The module will be assessed by coursework.

Topic 2: Interspecific competition

Topic 3: Predation
• Biological control and the harnessing of predators
